title: 111_s2959
content:
The "American Elections Act of 2010" prohibits foreign nationals from making contributions, donations, or expenditures in connection with federal, state, or local elections. Section 319 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions regarding corporations under foreign control or influence. This amendment prohibits such corporations from making contributions to elections. The amendment to Section 319 of the Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits corporations under foreign control from making contributions to elections if they have significant control over the corporation's voting shares, Board of Directors, or decision-making process related to election activities. The amendment to Section 319 of the Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits corporations under foreign control from making contributions to elections if they meet certain criteria, such as providing a majority of gross receipts or controlling a significant portion of voting shares. The amendment to Section 319 of the Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits corporations under foreign control from making contributions to elections if they meet certain criteria, such as controlling a majority of voting shares or a majority of the Board of Directors. Additionally, corporations must certify compliance with this section before engaging in any related activities. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF FOREIGN NATIONALS' INFLUENCE IN FEDERAL, STATE, OR LOCAL ELECTIONS. Section 318 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require clear disclosure of the percentage of voting shares controlled by a foreign national or the percentage of gross receipts received from a foreign national by a corporation paying for a communication. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require corporations to disclose the percentage of voting shares controlled by a foreign national or the percentage of gross receipts received from a foreign national when paying for a communication. Additionally, corporations with voting stock must provide supplemental audio statements for certain communications. Corporations must disclose the percentage of voting shares controlled by foreign nationals when paying for a communication. Additionally, corporations without voting stock must provide a specific audio statement for certain communications. Corporations without voting stock must include an audio statement disclosing the percentage of funds from foreign nationals in certain communications. Corporations without voting stock must include an audio statement disclosing funds from foreign nationals in certain communications, as defined in section 319(b). The second sentence of subparagraph (A) applies to a supplemental audio statement in the same manner as an audio statement under such subparagraph. SEC. 4. SEVERABILITY.

If any provision of this Act or amendment made by this Act is held unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act and its amendments apply to contributions and expenditures made 45 days after enactment.
